add-sub-node-1.title: Adding and Subtracting Fractions with Unlike Denominators
learningFocus: Find the least common denominator (LCD)
Convert fractions to equivalent fractions with common denominator
Add and subtract fractions with unlike denominators
Simplify answers to lowest terms
generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem only
DO NOT include mathTool - students should compute mentally or on paper
Ensure numerator is always less than denominator (proper fractions)
For subtraction, ensure minuend is greater than subtrahend to get positive result
Use proper LaTeX formatting: $\frac{a}{b}$
Include variety in question phrasing (Calculate, What is, Find, Work out)
Ensure answers can be simplified - include some that simplify and some that don't
Avoid fractions that are already in simplest form when LCD is used

add-sub-node-2.title: Adding Mixed Numbers
learningFocus: Add whole number parts first
Add fractional parts using common denominator
Convert improper fractions to mixed numbers when sum exceeds 1
Combine whole and fractional parts for final answer
generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem only
DO NOT include mathTool - students should compute on paper
Use LaTeX for mixed numbers: $a\frac{b}{c}$
Generate mix of problems: some where fraction sum < 1, some where sum > 1 (requires carry)
When fractions sum to more than 1, student must convert improper fraction and add to whole
Ensure all final answers are in simplest form
Avoid same denominators - focus on unlike denominators

add-sub-node-3.title: Subtracting Mixed Numbers (with Regrouping)
learningFocus: Recognize when regrouping (renaming) is needed
Regroup by converting 1 whole to equivalent fraction
Subtract mixed numbers after regrouping
Express answer in simplest form
generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem only
DO NOT include mathTool - students should compute on paper
CRITICAL: Include problems that REQUIRE regrouping (fractional part of minuend < subtrahend)
Also include some problems that don't require regrouping for variety
Include 'whole minus mixed' type (e.g., 5 - 1 3/7)
Use LaTeX for mixed numbers: $a\frac{b}{c}$
Ensure all final answers are positive and in simplest form

mult-frac-whole-node-1.title: Finding a Fraction OF a Whole Number
learningFocus: Understand 'fraction OF' means multiplication
Use bar model: divide into denominator parts, select numerator parts
Calculate using multiplication: (numerator × whole) ÷ denominator
Verify answer is reasonable (less than whole for proper fractions)
generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem only
DO NOT include mathTool - it would reveal the answer by showing parts
CRITICAL: Choose whole numbers that divide evenly by the denominator
Use proper fractions only (numerator < denominator)
Answers should always be whole numbers for this section
Use LaTeX for fractions: $\frac{a}{b}$
Emphasize the word 'of' in the question format

mult-frac-whole-node-2.title: Multiplying Fraction × Whole Number
learningFocus: Multiply numerator by whole number, keep denominator
Convert improper fraction results to mixed numbers
Recognize commutative property: a/b × n = n × a/b
Simplify when possible
generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem only
DO NOT include mathTool - students should compute on paper
Include variety: some results as proper fractions, some as whole numbers, some as mixed numbers
Mix the order: sometimes fraction × whole, sometimes whole × fraction
Use LaTeX: $\frac{a}{b} \times c$ or $c \times \frac{a}{b}$
When result is improper fraction, student should convert to mixed number
Ensure final answers are in simplest form

mult-frac-whole-node-3.title: Word Problems: Fraction of a Whole Number
learningFocus: Identify 'fraction of' situations in word problems
Draw bar models showing the whole divided into parts
Calculate the required fraction of the total
Include correct units in answer

exemplarProblems.problemText: A ribbon is 18 metres long. Sarah uses $\frac{2}{3}$ of the ribbon. How many metres of ribbon does she use?
There are 35 apples in a basket. $\frac{4}{5}$ of them are red. How many red apples are there?
A water tank holds 24 litres. $\frac{5}{8}$ of the tank is filled with water. How many litres of water are in the tank?

questionTypes: Find what remains after using fraction

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem only
DO NOT include mathTool - would reveal the answer
Choose totals that divide evenly by the denominator
Include units in both question and expected answer
Use real-world contexts appropriate for Primary 5
Mix question types: 'how much used' and 'how much left'
Use LaTeX for fractions: $\frac{a}{b}$
Ensure mathematical correctness in all generated values

mult-two-frac-node-1.title: Understanding Fraction × Fraction
learningFocus: Understand 'fraction OF fraction' as multiplication
Visualize using area model (rectangle divided twice)
Recognize that product is smaller than both factors
Connect visual model to symbolic multiplication
generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem only
DO NOT include mathTool - would reveal the answer
Focus on unit fractions (numerator = 1) for conceptual understanding
Use 'of' language to connect to real-world meaning
Use LaTeX for fractions: $\frac{1}{a}$
Keep numbers simple - this is for conceptual understanding
Result should always be smaller than both input fractions

mult-two-frac-node-2.title: Multiplying Two Fractions: Algorithm
learningFocus: Multiply numerators together
Multiply denominators together
Simplify final answer to lowest terms
Apply: (a/b) × (c/d) = (a×c)/(b×d)
generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem only
DO NOT include mathTool - students should compute on paper
Include both proper and improper fractions
Generate mix: some results need simplification, some don't
Use LaTeX: $\frac{a}{b} \times \frac{c}{d}$
Avoid fractions where cancellation is obvious (save for next section)
Ensure final answers are in simplest form

mult-two-frac-node-3.title: Cancellation (Simplifying Before Multiplying)
learningFocus: Identify common factors between any numerator and any denominator
Cancel (divide both by common factor) before multiplying
Recognize that cancellation makes numbers smaller and easier
Understand why cancellation works mathematically
generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem only
DO NOT include mathTool - students should compute on paper
CRITICAL: Only generate fractions where cancellation IS possible
The question text should hint at using cancellation
Choose fractions where a numerator shares a factor with the OTHER fraction's denominator
Use LaTeX: $\frac{a}{b} \times \frac{c}{d}$
Final answer should be in simplest form
Avoid trivial cancellations (like both having factor of 2)

mult-mixed-node-1.title: Multiplying Mixed Number × Whole Number
learningFocus: Convert mixed number to improper fraction
Multiply improper fraction by whole number
Convert product back to mixed number
Use cancellation when possible
generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem only
DO NOT include mathTool - students should compute on paper
Use LaTeX for mixed numbers: $a\frac{b}{c}$
Mix the order: sometimes mixed × whole, sometimes whole × mixed
Ensure final answer is expressed as a mixed number (not improper fraction)
Include some problems where cancellation can simplify the calculation
Keep numbers reasonable for Primary 5 level

mult-mixed-node-2.title: Visualizing Mixed Number × Whole Number
learningFocus: Visualize mixed × whole as repeated groups
Draw models showing the multiplication
Connect visual model to numerical calculation
Verify answers using diagrams

exemplarProblems.problemText: Draw a model to show $1\frac{1}{2} \times 3$ and find the answer.
Use a visual model to calculate $2\frac{1}{4} \times 2$.
Show how to find $1\frac{1}{3} \times 3$ using a diagram.

questionFormats: Draw a model to show {mixed} × {whole} and find the answer.
Use a visual model to calculate {mixed} × {whole}.
Show how to find {mixed} × {whole} using a diagram.

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem only
DO NOT include mathTool - students should draw their own diagrams
Keep numbers small for easy visualization (multiplier ≤ 4)
Choose fractions that combine nicely (e.g., 3 × ⅓ = 1)
Include explanation of visual reasoning in the expected answer
Use LaTeX for mixed numbers: $a\frac{b}{c}$
Questions should explicitly ask for visual/model approach

mult-mixed-node-3.title: Word Problems: Mixed Number × Whole Number
learningFocus: Identify multiplication situations in word problems
Set up mixed number × whole number correctly
Calculate and express answer with appropriate units
Verify answer is reasonable in context

exemplarProblems.problemText: Each piece of string is $2\frac{1}{5}$ metres long. What is the total length of 4 pieces of string?
A recipe uses $1\frac{1}{2}$ cups of flour. How much flour is needed for 3 batches?
Each bottle contains $1\frac{3}{8}$ litres of juice. How much juice is in 6 bottles?
A bag of sand weighs $2\frac{2}{3}$ kg. What is the total weight of 9 bags?

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem only
DO NOT include mathTool - students should solve on paper
Use real-world contexts appropriate for Primary 5
Include units in both question and expected answer
Choose contexts where multiplication makes sense (identical items)
Use LaTeX for mixed numbers: $a\frac{b}{c}$
Ensure answers are reasonable (not excessively large)
Include some problems where result is a whole number (special case)
